title: INTERSPEECH_2013_21_abs

sentences.text: This work proposes a new research direction to address the lack of structures in traditional n-gram models .
It is based on a weakly supervised dependency parser that can model speech syntax without relying on any annotated training corpus .
Labeled data is replaced by a few hand-crafted rules that encode basic syntactic knowledge .
Bayesian inference then samples the rules , disambiguating and combining them to create complex tree structures that maximize a discriminative model 's posterior on a target unlabeled corpus .
This posterior encodes sparse se-lectional preferences between a head word and its dependents .
The model is evaluated on English and Czech newspaper texts , and is then validated on French broadcast news transcriptions .

Entity-a_new_research_direction.label: a new research direction
Entity-a_new_research_direction.description: A novel approach to modeling speech syntax without relying on annotated training corpora, which proposes the use of weakly supervised dependency parsers and Bayesian inference to create complex tree structures.

Entity-this_work.label: This work
Entity-this_work.description: A novel approach to dependency parsing for modeling speech syntax without relying on annotated training corpora, proposing a new research direction to address the lack of structures in traditional n-gram models.

Entity-that_can_model_speech_syntax_with.label: that can model speech syntax without relying on any annotated training corpus
aliases: that can model speech syntax without relying on any annotated training corpus
Entity-that_can_model_speech_syntax_with.description: A methodology or approach for modeling speech syntax using a weakly supervised dependency parser, which does not rely on any annotated training corpus.

mentions.local_name: that can model speech syntax without relying on any annotated training corpus

Entity-the_lack_of_structure_in_traditio.label: the lack of structures in traditional n-gram models
aliases: the lack of structures in traditional n-gram models
Entity-the_lack_of_structure_in_traditio.description: A limitation inherent in classical n-gram-based approaches, characterized by the absence of structural representations and relationships between words.

mentions.local_name: the lack of structures in traditional n-gram models

Entity-it.label: It
Entity-it.description: A new research direction or approach proposed to address the lack of structures in traditional n-gram models.

Entity-a_discriminative_model_s_posterio.label: a discriminative model's posterior on a target unlabeled corpus
aliases: a discriminative model's posterior on a target unlabeled corpus
Entity-a_discriminative_model_s_posterio.description: The probability distribution of a dependency parser that maximizes its likelihood given an input text, based on learned rules and syntactic knowledge.

mentions.local_name: a discriminative model's posterior on a target unlabeled corpus

Entity-traditional_n-gram_model.label: traditional n-gram models
Entity-traditional_n-gram_model.description: A statistical language processing technique that analyzes sequences of n items (e.g., words, characters) to identify patterns and relationships.

Entity-weakly_supervised_dependency_pars.label: weakly supervised dependency parser
Entity-weakly_supervised_dependency_pars.description: A software tool or algorithm that uses minimal supervision to analyze sentence structure and relationships between words, often requiring less labeled data than traditional dependency parsers.

Entity-the_rule.label: the rules
Entity-the_rule.description: Hand-crafted syntactic rules used in a weakly supervised dependency parser to encode basic syntactic knowledge and create complex tree structures.

Entity-this_posterior.label: This posterior
Entity-this_posterior.description: A probabilistic representation of selective syntactic relationships between a head word and its dependents.

Entity-sparse_se-lectional_preference_be.label: sparse se-lectional preferences between a head word and its dependents
aliases: sparse se-lectional preferences between a head word and its dependents
Entity-sparse_se-lectional_preference_be.description: The concept of preferring certain relationships or dependencies between words, particularly between a main word (head) and its related words (dependents), with these preferences being sparse and limited.

mentions.local_name: sparse se-lectional preferences between a head word and its dependents

Entity-speech_syntax.label: speech syntax
Entity-speech_syntax.description: The rules or patterns governing the structure of spoken language.

Entity-dependency_parser.label: dependency parser
Entity-dependency_parser.description: A software tool or system that analyzes and interprets grammatical relationships between words, such as subject-verb-object dependencies.

Entity-bayesian_inference.label: Bayesian inference
Entity-bayesian_inference.description: A statistical method or algorithm used for drawing conclusions from uncertain data, typically involving the calculation of probabilities and updating beliefs based on new information.

Entity-annotated_training_corpus.label: annotated training corpus
Entity-annotated_training_corpus.description: A collection of labeled examples used to train and evaluate machine learning models.

Entity-target_unlabeled_corpus.label: target unlabeled corpus
Entity-target_unlabeled_corpus.description: A collection of data instances without predefined labels or categories.

Entity-a_few_hand-crafted_rule_that_enco.label: a few hand-crafted rules that encode basic syntactic knowledge
aliases: a few hand-crafted rules that encode basic syntactic knowledge
Entity-a_few_hand-crafted_rule_that_enco.description: A set of manually created guidelines or principles that capture fundamental understanding of sentence structure and syntax.

Entity-a_discriminative_model_s_posterio.description: The probability distribution resulting from the application of a statistical model's parameters

Entity-dependent.label: dependents
Entity-dependent.description: Words or phrases that grammatically rely on another word for their meaning, structure, or function.

Entity-discriminative_model.label: discriminative model
Entity-discriminative_model.description: A statistical machine learning algorithm designed to predict categorical outcomes by maximizing the probability of correct classification.

Entity-tree_structure.label: tree structures
Entity-tree_structure.description: A hierarchical organization of nodes or elements, often used in computer science and computational modeling to represent relationships between data.

Entity-posterior.description: A statistical representation of probability distribution that describes the uncertainty or randomness associated with an event, outcome, or variable.

Entity-complex_tree_structure.label: complex tree structures
Entity-complex_tree_structure.description: A hierarchical organization of nodes or elements, characterized by branching relationships and possibly recursive patterns.

Entity-french_broadcast_news_transcripti.label: French broadcast news transcriptions
Entity-french_broadcast_news_transcripti.description: A collection of written records or transcripts of French television and radio broadcasts, typically featuring news programs.

Entity-hand-crafted_rule.label: hand-crafted rules
Entity-hand-crafted_rule.description: A set of manually created and defined rules, often used to govern or guide decision-making processes.

Entity-labeled_data.label: Labeled data
Entity-labeled_data.description: A collection of data instances with corresponding labels or annotations.

Entity-head_word.label: head word
Entity-head_word.description: A fundamental unit of language that conveys meaning through its form, often used as the core or central element of a phrase or sentence.

Entity-new_research_direction.label: new research direction
Entity-new_research_direction.description: A novel approach or perspective for conducting research

Entity-rule.label: rules
Entity-rule.description: A set of guidelines or algorithmic instructions

Entity-czech_newspaper_text.description: A collection of written articles published by newspapers in the Czech Republic.

Entity-english.description: A West Germanic language spoken in the United Kingdom and widely used as a global lingua franca.

Entity-work.description: A planned or ongoing effort, such as a project or program, focused on achieving specific goals or objectives.

Entity-newspaper_text.label: newspaper texts
Entity-newspaper_text.description: Written articles or reports published in print or online newspapers.

Entity-french.label: French
Entity-french.description: A Romance language spoken in France and several other countries, or a country located primarily in Western Europe.

Entity-czech.label: Czech
Entity-czech.description: A Slavic language spoken by people of Czech nationality or a country located in Central Europe.

summary: This work proposes a new research direction to address the lack of structures in traditional n-gram models . It is based on a weakly supervised dependency parser that can model speech syntax without relying on any annotated training corpus . Labeled data is replaced by a few hand-crafted rules that encode basic syntactic knowledge . Bayesian inference then samples the rules , disambiguating and combining them to create complex tree structures that maximize a discriminative model 's posterior on a target unlabeled corpus . This posterior encodes sparse se-lectional preferences between a head word and its dependents . The model is evaluated on English and Czech newspaper texts , and is then validated on French broadcast news transcriptions .

Predicate-proposes.label: proposes
Predicate-proposes.description: To propose something means to suggest or recommend it as an idea or plan for consideration and potential implementation. The predicate 'proposes' indicates that the subject (in this case, a work) presents or offers its object (a new research direction) as a viable option for further exploration or development.

Predicate-address.label: address
Predicate-address.description: The predicate 'address' indicates a connection between an issue or problem (subject) and a potential solution or approach (object), suggesting that the subject can be resolved or tackled through the means described by the object.

Predicate-is_based_on.label: is based on
Predicate-is_based_on.description: Indicates that a subject relies on or uses an object as its foundation, justification, or underlying principle. The relationship suggests that the subject's existence, validity, or functionality is grounded in or derived from the characteristics of the object.

Predicate-can_model.label: can model
Predicate-can_model.description: The predicate 'can model' indicates that a subject (a system or algorithm) has the capability to represent or generate an object (typically a type of data, syntax, or structure), often through some form of abstraction, simplification, or transformation.

Predicate-model.label: model
Predicate-model.description: To represent or simulate something (e.g. a system, process, or phenomenon) using a set of rules, patterns, or principles that capture its essential characteristics.

Predicate-replaced_by.label: replaced by
Predicate-replaced_by.description: The predicate 'replaced by' indicates a substitution or alternative relationship between two entities. It suggests that one entity (the subject) has been substituted, superseded, or taken the place of another entity (the object), often implying a change or improvement.

Predicate-samples.label: samples
Predicate-samples.description: To sample means to select or extract a subset of instances from a larger population or dataset, often for purposes such as testing hypotheses, evaluating models, or generating insights. The predicate 'samples' connects the subject (a process or method) with the object (the rules or guidelines that govern the sampling procedure), indicating how the subject operates on the object to produce a representative subset.

Predicate-samples_the.label: samples the
Predicate-samples_the.description: The predicate 'samples the' indicates that the subject (in this case Bayesian inference) extracts or selects specific instances from a larger set of possibilities represented by the object (rules). This process involves identifying and isolating relevant information, patterns, or relationships within the rules to inform decision-making or draw conclusions.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: Indicates that the subject concept is subsumed or encompassed by the object concept. The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between two concepts, where the subject is a more specific instance of the object.
